===Origins===
After the [[Post-Hyborian Cataclysm]], the territory around the slowly dying [[Vilayet Sea|Inland Sea]] was inhabited with [[Cimmerians]], where retreating [[Glossary:Nordheimr|Nordics]] joined them, living more or less at peace together, while the two races eventually intermingled.<!-- {{r|Savage Sword of Conan #17|; The Hyborian Age: The Darkness... and the Dawn}} -->

Due to a growing population, the tribes, now known as the '''Aryans''' living in the steppes west of the Inland Sea (now know as the [[Caspian Sea|Caspian]]).<!-- {{r|Savage Sword of Conan #17|; The Hyborian Age: The Darkness... and the Dawn}} -->

They pushed westwards the remnants of the [[Picts (Earth-616)|Picts]], returned to [[Stone Age]] savages, and moved into the lands now known as [[India]], [[Asia Minor]], and much of [[Europe]].{{r|Savage Sword of Conan #17|; The Hyborian Age: The Darkness... and the Dawn}}

===[[Modern Age]]===
Some variations of the primitive sons of Aryas remained in the [[Modern Age]], though other vanished ages ago.{{r|Savage Sword of Conan #17|; The Hyborian Age: The Darkness... and the Dawn}}<!-- unclear if the Nemedians of Irish legends, the Danes, Achaiains, Gauls, Britons and Gaels are supposed to be included within the Aryans.

| Notes                   = * {{WP|Aryan}} was originally a term used as ethnic and religious labels.<!-- {{r|{{WP|Aryans|Aryan at Wikipedia.org}}}} -->
** Drawing on misinterpreted references in the 19th century, the term "Aryan" was adopted as a racial category by French writer Arthur de Gobineau, whose ideology of the "Aryan" race was based on an idea of blond northern European who had migrated across the world and founded all major civilizations, before being diluted through racial mixing with local populations. This later influenced the Nazi racial ideology which saw the "Aryan race" as innately superior to other putative racial groups.{{r|{{WP|Aryans|Aryan at Wikipedia.org}}}}
* In his pseudo-historical essay "[https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/The_Hyborian_Age The Hyborian Age]", [[Robert E. Howard|Robert E. Howard]] seemingly used the latter misinterpretation.
